title: How to Fence a Garden

steps.headline: Keep in mind it is important to leave enough room between the fence and the actual growing area to permit you to move around the plants.
Measure the area that is to be fenced with a measuring tape, including the height you want the fence to be.
Choose the material you plan to use as your fence.
Dig holes spaced evenly around your garden for your fence posts using a shovel or spade.
Fill each hole with either dirt or cement.
Cut and attach the material you will be using to fence a garden using a hammer (mallet), nails and wire cutters.
steps.description: Common materials used include wood slats, chicken wire, vinyl netting or mesh. You can also choose more decorative materials.

steps.headline: Include an easy access gate or opening for you to enter the garden.

text:
Keep in mind it is important to leave enough room between the fence and the actual growing area to permit you to move around the plants. Measure the area that is to be fenced with a measuring tape, including the height you want the fence to be. Choose the material you plan to use as your fence. Several types are available, such as wood, wire and mesh. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a3/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a3/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Dig your post holes deep enough to bury half the pole. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add gravel to cover the bottom of the hole before setting the post. This will help with drainage. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Dig holes spaced evenly around your garden for your fence posts using a shovel or spade. Fill each hole with either dirt or cement. When using dirt, make sure you continuously compress the dirt as you add it to the hole. This makes for a solid, tight fit. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If you choose cement as your base, you will need to stabilize the post until the cement sets. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut and attach the material you will be using to fence a garden using a hammer (mallet), nails and wire cutters. Common materials used include wood slats, chicken wire, vinyl netting or mesh. You can also choose more decorative materials. Include an easy access gate or opening for you to enter the garden. A simple gate can be made by extending the length of the materials used approximately 1 foot (0.3 meters). {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add some hooks onto the extension in order to attach the gate to the fence when you want it closed. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}
sentences: Keep in mind it is important to leave enough room between the fence and the actual growing area to permit you to move around the plants.
Measure the area that is to be fenced with a measuring tape, including the height you want the fence to be.
Choose the material you plan to use as your fence.
Several types are available, such as wood, wire and mesh.

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Dig your post holes deep enough to bury half the pole.

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add gravel to cover the bottom of the hole before setting the post.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3a\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3a\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-3Bullet3-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Dig holes spaced evenly around your garden for your fence posts using a shovel or spade.
Fill each hole with either dirt or cement.
When using dirt, make sure you continuously compress the dirt as you add it to the hole.
This makes for a solid, tight fit.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ee\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ee\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} If you choose cement as your base, you will need to stabilize the post until the cement sets.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/54\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/54\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-5Bullet2-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut and attach the material you will be using to fence a garden using a hammer (mallet), nails and wire cutters.
Common materials used include wood slats, chicken wire, vinyl netting or mesh.
You can also choose more decorative materials.
Include an easy access gate or opening for you to enter the garden.
A simple gate can be made by extending the length of the materials used approximately 1 foot (0.3 meters).

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0e\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-460px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0e\/Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg\/v4-760px-Fence-a-Garden-Step-7Bullet1-Version-2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add some hooks onto the extension in order to attach the gate to the fence when you want it closed.
tyn_section: Measuring tape to measure the area to be fenced and distances between posts
Wood or vinyl for the posts
